title: Meet and Eat
description: Time to kick off camp! Join us for some snacks and getting to know your fellow campers!

title: Introduction to Max/MSP/Jitter
description: Max/MSP/Jitter is a multimedia authoring environment that enables you to create programs for real-time manipulation of media (data, audio, video, 3d). It is used in performance and installations by artists, composers, and people just like you!

title: Creative Coding with Processing
description: This workshop will give you an introduction to the basic principles of creative coding with Processing. Processing is an open-source coding platform used by designers and developers to create interactive installations, data visualizations, software tools, and much much more.

title: Introduction to User Experience (UX)
description: What is User Experience?

title: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium
description: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium is the first installment of a 3 part series on creating narratives within in the framework of a app. This lecture is a survey of current artists and projects using the mobile platform to create innovative narrative forms (i.e: Christoph Niemann’s “Petting Zoo”,  David Benqué’s “The Infinite Adventure Machine”, Works from “Les Editions Volumiques” etc…).

title: Product Design/DigiFab
description: We will be covering design tools (software and hardware) for digital fabrication.

title: ITP Mappathon: Content Making for Projection Mapping
description:
Step 1
 This week, we will learn how to make visual content using Modul8.
 We will use a png, a jpg and a movie files to make a moving image using Modul8. This method is a great tool to camp your idea.

title: Shop Safety!
description: Get Shop certified!

title: Introduction to Soft Circuits
description: In this class, we will go over conductive materials used in creating soft circuits, such as different thread, fabrics, inks and fasteners, along with looking at microcontrollers designed specifically for wearable electronics. Projects that have been created utilizing these techniques will also be shown. We will then create a simple soft circuit with a switch and that lights up a LED. Attendees will have the chance to learn or expand on basic hand sewing techniques and experience working with new materials and skills.
comment: Hi Judgeworks: This is just a super basic intro class so we won’t be going over muscle wire specifically.  I saw on the community board that there was interest in people doing a session using muscle wire so maybe we can talk about it during the workshop and see who else is interested!

title: Introduction to Soft Circuits
description: In this class, we will go over conductive materials used in creating soft circuits, such as different thread, fabrics, inks and fasteners, along with looking at microcontrollers designed specifically for wearable electronics. Projects that have been created utilizing these techniques will also be shown. We will then create a simple soft circuit with a switch and that lights up a LED. Attendees will have the chance to learn or expand on basic hand sewing techniques and experience working with new materials and skills.
comment:

title: Acrylic Cutting and Bending
description: Learn a fast and easy way to prototype precision parts using the laser cutter.  And then literally take it in a new direction with the acrylic bender.  Quickly turn 2D parts into 3 dimensional objects.

title: Intro to the Soft Lab
description: This workshop will introduce you to the basics of using ITP’s soft lab resources — specifically the sewing machines, the embroidery machine, and the vinyl cutter.  This will mostly be a demo session, so no materials are required!

title: Intro to After Effects
description: I’ll be attending.

title: Wearables Hack Day
description: Do you sew? Do you play with microcontrollers? Then join us for ITP Camp wearables hack day!

title: Sensing our surroundings : log sensor data using arduino
description: This hands on workshop will address visualizing data input from Arduino. The context of the class will be based around open source semi-autonomous sailing robots called Protei, designed to sense & clean oceans. After a brief introduction about Protei project, the remainder of the session will be devoted to understanding the very basics of sensing & exploring the environment through collecting & visualizing data using remote sensors, including sensors such as photocells, potentiometers, and more complex ones like barometers, GPS, and accelerometers.

title: Really Big Video Part 1
description: This session will introduce Big Building Mapping and Video Projection. I will begin by showing examples of site-specific and video mapping pieces and then we will map a real building using a spatial scan in Mad Mapper. For homework each camper will get a scan to work from and some tips on how to create giant projections. Part 2 of the session will allow campers to showcase their mapped work projected 3 stories tall on an actual building on broadway.

title: Connect iOS & Arduino with Bluetooth LE
description: This is a one hour crash course on how to get your iPhone (or iPad, or iPad touch) to talk to your Arduino using the new Bluetooth Low Energy (aka the Bluetooth 4.0) standard. I’ll look at the various hardware options, and do a “show and tell” with some of the available hardware that I’ll bring along for attendees to look over. I’ll finish off with a live coding demo that’ll walk people through the basics of sending data to and from an Arduino with the classic hardware “Hello World” project; I’ll blink an LED on and off, but this time I’ll do it from my iPhone over Bluetooth LE.

title: Re-wiring for Re-cycling
description: Physical Computing strikes me as a unique opportunity to recycle materials destined for landfill while creating unique objects and experiences. I’ve recently come to realize that a large part of my increased comfort level with electronics derives from a shift in perspective; no longer do I simply see a lonely rusted bike wheel littering my neighborhood, but raw materials such as spokes that make great axles for rotating propellers and mirrors. The VCR I found outside my friend’s studio became a drawer of motors, buttons, and a tape reader that now scans discarded video tapes in tandem with that bike tire! So for this session I’d like to lead a conceptual and hands on workshop in which we dream up ways to use discarded electronics (which I will provide). What inventive ways will we think to use an air mattress pump? A robotic aerosol sprayer? A game involving a levitating object? The possibilities are vast and can only improve with a conceptual shift concerning everyday objects.

title: Arduino Programming Basics
description: So if you want to move beyond the blinking LED and learn some more coding for the Arduino, this is the class for you. We’ll review some of the coding from Arduino 101 and then move onto variables, for loops, while loops, and writing your own functions.

title: Turning on the lathe
description: **YOU MUST HAVE HAD A SHOP SAFETY TRAINING IN ORDER TO TAKE THIS CLASS.  NO EXCEPTIONS.**

title: 3D Scanning Workshop with the Kinect & ReconstructMe
description: We’ll explore 3D scanning using an Xbox Kinect controller with ReconstructMe software, and the steps needed to convert these scans to 3D printable models. I have built a rig for doing full body human scans. The rig builds on this turntable I built last year: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28454 We’ll cover my scanning technique then a workflow for taking scans to a printable mesh using Netfabb Basic. I can also touch on some tricks with Meshlab if we need to combine meshes, remesh or reduce polygon count.

title: From Story to Tech: a methodology project
description: Often times, it seems that tech projects can come off as nothing more than technological masturbation. Many of us know what it’s like to witness a new project with cutting-edge tech only to feel disappointed, likening the experience more to a technical demo than something poignant and worth remembering. This may happen with projects of any nature, of course, but tech projects are especially prone to the pitfall of gadgetry taking precedence over meaning.

title: Wearable and Mobile Accessories
description: Kate Hartman and Shawn Van Every will give a tour through some of the recent wireless and wearable platforms and products that are emerging and give a workshop on how we might prototype some ideas of our own.

title: Faster Fashion – Rapid Prototyping and the Things We Wear
Beat Making for Babies
description: Beat Making for Babies is a fool proof introduction to making music with your computer. We’ll cover the basics of how to make simple beats using Midi, crafting beats from original & found sounds, and the seeds of combining our beats with emerging technologies.

title: Aerial Photography of Fresh Kills Landfill
description: Fresh Kills is one of the most infamous landfills in the United States containing all of New York city’s waste for over 50 years.  Visible from space and as large as the Great Wall of China, Fresh Kills is a New York secret located in Staten Island and currently being converted into a public park over the next thirty years.  Join us for a field trip to this epic landscape to discover the final resting place of our trash and experiment with aerial photography using kites and large helium balloons.  WIth these grassroots mapping techniques, we can begin to develop a high resolution map of the landfill, investigate vegetation growth and begin to better understand what happens to the things we throw away.

title: EAGLE PCB Design Software – Intro Session
